en: This miniature portrait, likely painted after c.1630 by John Hoskins (1590/95-1664/65), has likely suffered from a significant degree of fading that has affected the carnation in particular. It is likely that fugitive lakes were employed to model this passage, which have lost their colour. The result is that the face is now characterised by very strong contrasts and lacks smooth transitions between light and shade.

The miniature is in a good state of preservation. 
The UV image shows an orange UV colour on the flesh tone, suggesting the use of lead white. 

The lead (Pb) and calcium (Ca) MA-XRF maps show a possible change in the shape of the hat.
Calcium, likely as chalk, is used to paint the base layer of the ruff, whereas the lace is painted with lead white, and is also used to modulate the bone black of the doublet.
